name: Appeal to Authority
definition: Using someone's status or credentials as proof of a claim, especially outside their expertise or without real evidence.
whyItWorks: We trust experts because we can't check everything ourselves. But someone's title isn't proof—a famous scientist's opinion on nutrition isn't the same as actual nutrition research.

examples.text: My older brother got into Harvard, so his advice on how to study is definitely right.
examples.analysis: Getting into a good school doesn't make someone an expert on learning. What worked for him might not work for you.

examples.text: This fitness protocol is backed by Dr. Andrew Huberman, a Stanford neuroscientist.
examples.analysis: He's a real scientist, but neuroscience credentials don't automatically make nutrition advice correct. You still need good evidence.

examples.text: 9 out of 10 doctors recommend this supplement.
examples.analysis: Which doctors? Paid by the company? What does 'recommend' even mean? Vague expert claims are weak evidence.

examples.text: A retired federal judge says our sentencing guidelines are just right.
examples.analysis: One judge's opinion isn't consensus. Judges can disagree, and they have their own values and blind spots.

examples.text: This investment strategy is used by billionaires like Warren Buffett.
examples.analysis: You don't hear about the strategies that failed. Billionaires' situation and risks are totally different from most people's.

examples.text: My favorite YouTuber says this diet works—she has millions of followers, so she must know what she's talking about.
examples.analysis: Follower count isn't a nutrition degree. Popularity doesn't prove the claims are true.

examples.text: Our principal says social media is always toxic, so it has to be true.
examples.analysis: Principals have authority at school, but that doesn't make them experts on every topic, including mental health research.

examples.text: A Nobel Prize–winning economist says deportations will crash the economy.
examples.analysis: Awards don't make every opinion automatically right, especially on complex policies with many moving parts.

examples.text: A best-selling author says cancel culture is destroying free speech.
examples.analysis: Selling lots of books shows popularity, not necessarily that their take is carefully researched or balanced.

examples.text: A major bank's research team says housing is still affordable for most people.
examples.analysis: Institutional reports can be biased too. You still need to look at how they measured 'affordable' and what they left out.

promptStarters: Even ___, who is a respected ___, agrees that ___.
